questions.text: A patient comes with long-standing non-pitting edema in the legs. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Lymphedema is the most probable cause of long-standing non-pitting edema in the limbs.

Lymphedema is the abnormal accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitial spaces of the tissues.

Lymphedema can be primary or secondary.

Primary lymphedema includes: 

  • Lymphedema congenita (0-2 years): more common in males, involves multiple limbs, face, and genitalia. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is called Nonne Milroy syndrome.
  • Lymphedema praecox (2-35 years): more common in females, the most common type of primary lymphedema with a peak incidence in puberty. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is called Meig's disease.
  • Lymphedema tarda (>35 years): Rare and uncommon.

Secondary lymphedema is more common than primary and is the most common cause of lymphedema overall. Causes include lymph node dissection (axillary or inguinal), post-mastectomy, postoperative radiotherapy, obesity, varicose vein surgery, and trauma.

Complications of lymphedema include infections, skin changes, recurent cellulitis, non-healing ulcers, and lymphangiosarcoma.

Treatment mostly includes patient education and nonsurgical interventions, which include limb elevation, and external compressive garments. When the above methods fail, surgery can be considered.

questions.text: A patient comes to you with complaints of long-standing swelling of the left leg, as shown in the image. The swelling disappears in the morning and on examination, pitting is seen. What grade of lymphedema is this?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, pitting edema which disappears completely on elevation and bed rest indicates grade I lymphedema, according to Brunner's classification.

Skin changes seen in lymphedema include peau d'orange, erythema, hyperkeratosis, ulceration, stemmer sign, and buffalo hump.

Stemmer sign is the inability to pinch a fold of skin on the dorsum of the toes due to lymphedema. 

Clinical classification of lymphedema:

Grade (Brunner)

Clinical features

Subclinical

There is excessive interstitial fluid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes, but no clinically apparent lymphedema.

Grade I

Edema pits on pressure and the swelling completely disappears on elevation and bed rest.

Grade II

Edema does not pit and does not significantly reduce on elevation

Grade III

Edema is associated with irreversible skin changes, i.e. fibrosis and papillae.

questions.text: While examining a patient with lymphoedema, you are unable to pinch the skin of the patient on the base of the toes. What is this sign called?
questions.solution:
In lymphedema, skin on the base of the toes cannot be pinched due to subcutaneous fibrosis. This sign is called Stemmer’s sign.

Sign Description
Stemmer's sign

Seen in lymphoedema

Skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched due to Subcutaneous Fibrosis.
Frank's sign

A diagonal crease in the earlobe that runs backward from the tragus at a 45-degree angle across the lobule to the rear edge of the auricle.

May be a predictor of coronary artery disease.
Levine's sign

Clenched fist held over the chest to describe ischemic chest pain.
Winterbottom's sign

Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy in african trypanosomiasis.

questions.text: An 8-month-old girl child was brought to the hospital with complaints of swelling of both feet as shown in the image. On examination pitting is seen. Her ECG, RFT, and urine analysis were normal. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has Milroy disease which is the familial version of congenital lymphedema. It is inherited as a dominant trait.

Primary lymphedema is classified on the basis of age of onset and the presence of familial clustering. 

  1. Congenital lymphoedema - onset before 2 years of age
  2. Lymphedema precox - most common type. onset between 2 to 35 years of age
  3. Lymphedema tarda - rare. onset after 35 years of age 
Features Congenital lymphoedma  Lymphedema precox
Onset Before 2nd year of life  Between 2-35 years of life

Extent

Extends to multiple limbs, genitalia, and/or the face

 Mostly unilateral and extends only to the knees
Eponyms Known as Milroy disease Known as Meige's disease
Sexual predilection None More common in females

Treatment includes conservative management such as massage, compression stockings, or bandaging.

Surgical management includes vascularized lymph node transfer (VLNT). It involves the transfer of functional lymph nodes from a healthy donor site to an area of the body with damaged or diseased lymphatic drainage.

questions.text: Which of the following will you perform when asked to do a lymphangiography of the leg?

choices.text: Inject sodium diatrizoate subcutaneously on the dorsum of the foot
Inject sodium diatrizoate retrogradely under pressure into a small vein on the dorsum of foot
Dissect the lymphatics through an incision on the dorsum of foot and injecting contrast
Insertion of guidewire into the lymphatic system of the leg and inject contrast

questions.solution:
Direct contrast lymphangiography is done by dissecting the lymphatic vasculature through an incision on the dorsum of the foot and injecting contrast. 

Direct contrast lymphangiography is an invasive study done to visualise the lymphatic system. It involves exposure and cannulation of lymphatics and slow injection of contrast medium such as ethiodized oil.

Complications:

  • Damage to the visualized lymphatics
  • Allergic reactions
  • Pulmonary embolism if the oil-based contrast agent enters the venous system through lymphovenous anastomosis.

Contrast mag­netic resonance lymphangiography is a newer testing method. It is performed after intracutaneous injection of gadobenate dimeglumine into the interdigital webs of the dorsal foot. 

It is capable of visualizing the anatomy and functional status of lymph flow transport of lymphatic vessels and lymph nodes of lymphedematous limbs.

Image A shows a lymphangiography with normal uptake.

Image B shows a lymphangiography scan with no uptake in Milroy's disease.

Image C depicts a lymphangiography scan in a patient with lymphoedema and reflux.

questions.text: Which of the following complications are least likely to develop, in patients with chronic lymphoedema?
questions.solution:
Marjolin's ulcers are unlikely to develop in patients with chronic lymphedema.

Marjolin’s ulcers are malignant ulcers that develop over chronic scars, most commonly from burns. Marjolin's ulcer may also develop in chronic long standing venous ulcers but are not seen in chronic lymphedema. 

Initially, the lymphedema is soft and pits on the pressure but with time the skin becomes thickened and non-pitting due to fibrosis, dermal thickening, and hyperkeratosis.

Frequent episodes of lymphangitis and cellulitis may occur. This is due to loss of local immune defense mechanisms. Chronic eczema, the fungal infection of skin and nails, fissuring, verrucae, and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced disease.

Rarely malignancy (lymphangiosarcoma or angiosarcoma) may occur in chronic lymphedema. This neoplastic transformation of blood vessels and lymphatics is called Stewart-Treves syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding mediastinal lymphoma is false?

choices.text: Middle mediastinum is the most common site of mediastinal lymphoma
Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice
Video assisted thoracoscopy is used to diagnose the condition

questions.solution:
Anterior compartment is the most common site of lymphoma in the mediastinum. Other sites include the middle compartment and hilar nodes.

Primary mediastinal lymphoma is an uncommon type of lymphoma. Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL), primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma (PMBCL), and T-lymphoblastic lymphoma are the most common primary mediastinal lymphomas. In about 50% of patients who have both Hodgkin’s and Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, the mediastinum may be the primary site.

Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome refers to symptoms produced by the obstruction of blood flow through the SVC by the enlarging mediastinal mass, resulting in symptoms of dyspnea, facial and upper-extremity edema, cough, chest pain, and dysphagia.

Video-assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) is used to obtain a biopsy of the mediastinal mass for confirmation and diagnosis.

Chemotherapy with six cycles of R-CHOP regimen is preferred. Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal anti-CD20 antibody and has become a standard component of treating all B-cell lymphoma histologies that express CD20. 

Note: Thymoma is the most common mediastinal tumor in adults (overall).

questions.text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of swelling in the neck as given in the image. Which of the following is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is a congenital sequestration of lymphatic channel
Sclerotherapy is not used in treatment

questions.solution:
The given image depicts a lymphangioma, also known as cystic hygroma. They are brilliantly transilluminant.

Lymphangiomas are congenital benign tumors of the lymphatic system. They are the isolated cystic mass of lymphatic tissue that has the ability to produce lymph. Over time the tumor enlarges due to the accumulation of lymph within the cyst.

Types of lymphangiomas: 

  • Simple or capillary lymphangioma: They occur subcutaneously in the head, neck, and axilla. They may also occur within the internal organs and connective tissues in the thoracic and abdominal cavities.
  • Cavernous lymphangioma or cystic hygroma: They also occur in the neck or axilla. Rarely they may occur in retroperitoneum.

Treatment includes surgical excision of the tumor and image-guided sclerotherapy.

If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excision or unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partial excisions.

Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now called lymphatic malformations.

  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: Where is lymphangiosarcoma most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
Lymphangiosarcoma is most commonly seen in post-mastectomy edema of the arm. 

Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare tumor that develops as a com­plication of long-standing lymph­edema. 

Clinically, the patients present with acute worsening of the edema and appearance of subcutaneous nodules that have a propensity toward hemorrhage and ulceration. 

The tumor can be treated, like other sarcomas, with preoperative chemotherapy and radiation followed by surgical excision, which usually may take the form of radical amputation. Overall, the prognosis is very poor.

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling involving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema involving the upper limb.

Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It is a common complication of breast cancer treatment involving axillary lymph node dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of lymphedema significantly.

Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in the limb size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb fatigue, and reduced limb mobility.

Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm >2 centimeters than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria.

Management:

Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices can help reduce swelling. 

Dry skin can be seen due to fluid accumulation, which can lead to cellulitis/skin infections. Using a low pH water-based moisturizer is helpful.

Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation.

Benzpyrones and flavonoids are some naturally occurring substances that may be of use to treat lymphedema.

Surgical options are lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking.

Other options:

Option B:   Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage.

Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous exercise and in weightlifters. The subclavian vein is compressed at the thoracic outlet. Painful swelling of the arm is observed.

Option D: Cellulitis usually presents with an ulcer and the skin is erythematous, swollen, and painful. Fever, chills, and rigor follow.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not a part of decongestive lymphoedema therapy (DLT)?

(i) Limb elevation

(ii) Simple lymphatic drainage

(iii) Diuretics

(iv) Homan’s procedure

(v) Pain relief
questions.solution:
Diuretics and Homan’s procedure are not a part of DLT, and are a part of drug therapy and surgical management.

Decongestive lymphoedema therapy (DLT) is the currently used method for controlling swelling in lymphoedema. It consists of 2 phases: intensive and maintenance.

Intensive phase includes:

  • Skin care: Prevent drying of skin and exposure to the sun, avoid venipuncture from the affected limb.
  • Limb elevation
  • Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) - Proximal massage along lymphatic channels.
  • Compression therapy: Multilayer lymphoedema bandaging (MLLB), Pneumatic lymphoedema stockings, Graded compression stockings (100% in the ankle/foot, 70% in the knee, 50% in mid-thigh, and 40% in the groin).
  • Exercise: Slow rhythmic isotonic movements are beneficial, while vigorous, anaerobic isometric exercises are to be avoided.

Standard MLLB is only done if ABPI is ≥0.8. It is contraindicated if ABPI is < 0.5.

Maintenance phase includes:

  • Simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) - It is a simple massage technique done by the patient.
  • Pain relief

questions.text: Which among the following is not a limb reduction surgery for lymphoedema?
questions.solution:
Kinmonth procedure is a bypass surgery done for lymphoedema not a limb reduction surgery.
Surgical management of lymphoedema is divided into bypass procedures, liposuction, and limb reduction procedures.

  • Bypass procedures include:
    • Neilubowicz procedure - anastomosing lymph nodes to the veins.
    • Kinmonth procedure - using ileal mucosal patch.
  • Limb reduction procedures include:
    • Sistrunk procedure - A wedge of skin and subcutaneous tissue is excised and the wound closed primarily. This is the most commonly carried out procedure to reduce the girth of the thigh.
    • Homan’s procedure - Skin flaps are raised, and then subcutaneous tissue is excised from beneath the flaps.
    • Thompson’s procedure - Modification of Homan’s procedure. 
    • Charles procedure - Excision of all of the skin and subcutaneous tissues down to the deep fascia, with coverage using split-skin grafts.
